byline.contributor: Ivan Nechepurenko reported from Moscow, and Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva. Sewell Chan contributed reporting from London, Marlise Simons from The Hague and Somini Sengupta from the United Nations.
byline.original: By IVAN NECHEPURENKO and NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin directs his government to withdraw from treaty that established International Criminal Court; Russian Foreign Ministry calls court ineffective and one-sided; move is largely symbolic, as Russia never ratified treaty and thus, like United States, does not fall under its jurisdiction, but comes as other nations have also withdrawn.

headline.print_headline: Russia Cuts Ties With International Criminal Court
headline.main: Russia Cuts Ties With International Criminal Court, Calling It ‘One-Sided’

keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
keywords.name: subject

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

snippet: It was largely a symbolic move — Russia, like the United States, has not ratified the treaty that created the court and is not under its jurisdiction....
lead_paragraph: It was largely a symbolic move — Russia, like the United States, has not ratified the treaty that created the court and is not under its jurisdiction.
